doc.after: YohÃ© began her career as a soprano, but within a short while her voice lowered into a contralto that was described as peculiar.[9] She debuted as May YohÃ© (May derived from her initials)[10] in January 1886 with the McCaull Comic Opera Company as Dilly Dimple in "The Little Tycoon," a comic opera by Willard Spencer, presented at Temple Theatre in Philadelphia[11] and in March of that year at the Standard Theatre in New York.[12][13] In March 1887, she appeared in McCaull's Broadway production of Lorraine, composed by Rudolph Dellinger to a libretto by Oscar Walther, which was adapted in English by William J. Henderson.[14] She then played in the same production at the Chicago Opera House. In that production, she sang the following song with much success:[15][16][17]
